close_symbols: OS_ObjectIdRelease (semantics when record pointer becomes invalid)
OS_CHECK_SIZE (macro definition / behavior on invalid sizes)
(symbol defining max stored resource-name length, e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME or equivalent)
explanation:
For a MISRA C analysis of potential out-of-bounds accesses from the string functions used in OS_GetResourceName the analyzer needs the following additional symbols and why:

- OS_common_record_t
  - To know the layout of the object record returned by OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken and to verify that record and its fields are valid to dereference.

- OS_common_record_t.name_entry (storage layout / max length)
  - Crucial to determine how many bytes are actually valid to read from record->name_entry (is it a pointer to a separately-allocated buffer, an in-struct fixed char array, what is its maximum capacity and null-termination guarantee).

- OS_ObjectIdGetById (prototype & semantics)
  - To know under what conditions it returns OS_SUCCESS and whether it guarantees the token/record become valid for subsequent access (e.g., locking/transaction semantics that ensure record stays accessible while token is held).

- OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken (prototype & lifetime/aliasing semantics)
  - To determine whether the returned OS_common_record_t* points to stable storage for the duration between the call and the matching OS_ObjectIdRelease, and whether reading name_entry is safe.

- OS_ObjectIdRelease (semantics when record pointer becomes invalid)
  - To know when the record (and name_entry) may become invalid; ensures the code does not access freed/invalid memory while the token is held or after release.

- OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl (prototype)
  - To confirm that the type mapping does not affect token/record validity or produce different records with different name storage semantics.

- OS_CHECK_POINTER (macro definition / behavior on NULL)
  - The function dereferences buffer[0] immediately after this check. The analyzer must know whether OS_CHECK_POINTER can return/abort, or otherwise guarantees buffer is non-NULL; otherwise buffer[0]=0 may be UB.

- OS_CHECK_SIZE (macro definition / behavior on invalid sizes)
  - Similarly, to know whether buffer_size is validated (non-zero, not huge) or whether the macro can return/abort; impacts correctness of subsequent length checks and arithmetic (buffer_size-1).

- OS_strnlen (implementation semantics)
  - The code relies on OS_strnlen(record->name_entry, buffer_size). The analyzer needs the exact behavior (does it behave like POSIX strnlen, returning at most the supplied max, does it read only up to that bound, does it require name_entry non-NULL) to reason about how many bytes are safe to copy and whether strnlen itself can read beyond record->name_entry bounds.

- memcpy (standard prototype / preconditions)
  - memcpy is the string handling function governed by the MISRA rule; the analyzer must know that memcpy(buffer, record->name_entry, name_len) requires both source and destination to have at least name_len bytes accessible. This plus knowledge of name_entry storage and buffer_size allows checking for out-of-bounds.

- OS_SUCCESS
  - To interpret the return_code check and reason whether the record access code path is executed only on success.

- OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG
  - To understand the error return and the branch that adjusts name_len to buffer_size-1; analyzer must check the arithmetic and ensure it cannot underflow or produce an out-of-range copy length.

- Symbol defining max stored resource-name length (e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME or equivalent)
  - If name_entry is a fixed array or the system imposes a maximum resource name length, the analyzer needs that constant to prove that copying name_len bytes from name_entry is within the source bounds (i.e., to verify record->name_entry length >= name_len).

Collectively these symbols let the next agent determine (1) whether strnlen and memcpy are used with lengths that respect the source and destination bounds, (2) whether any of the pre-check macros guarantee non-NULL and valid sizes, and (3) whether the record/name_entry pointer is valid and has sufficient storage while it is being read. Without these definitions it is not possible to prove or disprove a potential MISRA violation (access beyond object bounds).
